prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 12CO(1-0): Haro11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the 12CO(1-0) emission line at band 3 in the nearby starburst galaxy Haro11. The other basebands are chosen to detect the continuum. As the source is compact, a single pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select dual polarization and 4 spectral windows: 1 on the 12CO(1-0) line and the others at different frequencies to probe the continuum in the band. We choose a bandwidth of 1875 MHz to have enough velocity range for continuum measurements, with element resolution of 976 kHz (2.6 km/s). The expected CO line width is about 50 km/s and we can rebin the data to a velocity resolution of 5 to 10 km/s if necessary (ie. 5 spectral resolution elements). We will make use of the velocity information to separate clumps along the line of sight and/or analyze kinematics in the molecular gas.

From IR observations, we know that the emission from the cold material is compact and we expect to find the molecular clouds confined mostly to the 3 main star-forming knots of Haro11. These knots have typical sizes of 1'' and are separated by about 3''. Thus, the largest angular scale of interest to trace the cold emission is 3''. We choose an angular resolution of 1'', which is well suited for our objectives as it is able to separate the different star-forming clusters while most of the CO flux will fall within few resolution elements, therefore optimizing the signal-to-noise.

We propose to observe the CO(1-0) line at 115 GHz in band 3 with a single pointing since the galaxy (10'') falls within the field-of-view (FOV) of 55'' (similar FOV as Herschel/PACS). Based on our single-dish CO(2-1) and CO(3-2) data and radiative transfer modeling, we estimate a CO(1-0) peak flux density of 34 mJy. The exact spatial distribution of the CO emission is unknown but likely mainly distributed around the 3 star-forming knots of Haro11. Thus we aim to detect a faintest level (1/6 of the total emission) at a S/N of 5. The requested rms is 1.1 mJy per beam with channel width 10 km/s. The setups for band 3 will also allow us to obtain a continuum measurement (>20-sigma) at the same angular resolution. Estimates of the continuum are based on our dust modeling of the Herschel and LABOCA data (see figure 4 in the science justification) which give a total flux density of 6mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 12CO(2-1): Haro11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the 12CO(2-1) emission line at band 6 in the nearby starburst galaxy Haro11. The other basebands are chosen to detect the continuum. As the source is compact, a single pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select dual polarization and 4 spectral windows: 1 on the 12CO(2-1) line and the others at different frequencies to probe the continuum in the band. We choose a bandwidth of 1875 MHz to have enough velocity range for continuum measurements, with element resolution of 976 kHz (1.3 km/s). The expected CO line width is about 50 km/s and we can rebin the data to a velocity resolution of 10 km/s if necessary (ie. 5 spectral resolution elements). We will make use of the velocity information to separate clumps along the line of sight and/or analyze kinematics in the molecular gas.

A single pointing is sufficient to cover the galaxy. We choose an angular resolution of 1'' to match the desired resolution at 115 GHz in band 3. We expect the emission to be clumpy and thus will not miss any extended emission.

We propose to observe the 12CO(2-1) line at 230 GHz in band 6. Based on our single-dish 12CO(2-1) flux and with the goal to detect a faintest level corresponding to 1/6 of the total emission, we estimate a 12CO(2-1) peak flux density of 40 mJy/beam. We aim for a 5-sigma detection, and therefore expect an rms of 8.0 mJy per beam with channel width 10 km/s. The setups for band 6 will also allow us to obtain a continuum measurement (>20-sigma, estimated from our dust modeling of the Herschel and LABOCA data which give a total flux density of 16mJy) at the same angular resolution. Note: the achieved S/N over 1/3 of the source line width is not 19 as calculated by the Observing Tool but ~7.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 13CO(2-1): Haro11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the 13CO(2-1) emission line at band 6 in the nearby starburst galaxy Haro11. The other basebands are chosen to detect the continuum. As the source is compact, a single pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select the line spectral type, with dual polarization, bandwidth of 1875 MHz to have enough velocity range for continuum measurements, and velocity resolution (1.36 km/s). The line width is expected to be ~30 km/s, so we can rebin the data to 10 km/s.

A single pointing is sufficient to cover the galaxy. We choose an angular resolution of 1'' to match the desired resolution of the 12CO(2-1) science goal. We expect the emission to be clumpy and thus will not miss any extended emission.

We propose to observe the 13CO(2-1) line at 220 GHz in band 6. Based on our single-dish CO(2-1) and assumed 12CO/13CO intensity ratio of 20 (e.g., Glenn et al. 2001), we estimate a 13CO(2-1) peak flux density of 20.0 mJy. We distribute the total emission in the 3 star-forming knots of Haro11 and estimate a faintest level at 1/6 of the total emission. Therefore, we require an rms of 0.67 mJy/beam to detect the 13CO(2-1) line at a 5-sigma level (with channel width 10 km/s). Our simulation with the ALMA OST indicate that those choices are perfectly suited for your purposes (see figure 3 in the science justification). The setups for band 6 will also allow us to obtain a continuum measurement (>20-sigma, estimated from our dust modeling of the Herschel and LABOCA data) at the same angular resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 12CO(3-2): Haro11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the 12CO(3-2) emission line at band 7 in the nearby starburst galaxy Haro11. The other basebands are chosen to detect the continuum. As the source of emission is expected within 8'', a mini-map of 3 pointings centered on each star-forming cluster is preferable to a single pointing.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select dual polarization and 4 spectral windows: 1 on the 12CO(3-2) line and the others at different frequencies to probe the continuum in the band. We choose a bandwidth of 1875 MHz to have enough velocity range for continuum measurements, with element resolution of 976 kHz (0.86 km/s). The expected CO line width is about 50 km/s and we can rebin the data to a velocity resolution of 10 km/s if necessary (ie. 5 spectral resolution elements). We will make use of the velocity information to separate clumps along the line of sight and/or analyze kinematics in the molecular gas.

The FOV is 18'', the size of the galaxy ~10'', and the emission from the star-forming regions is expected within ~8''. To achieve a uniform sensitivity across those regions, we opt for a small and extremely time efficient mosaic with 3 pointings centered on each star-forming cluster and separated by 1/4 FWHM. We choose an angular resolution of 1'' to match the desired resolution at 115 GHz in band 3.

We propose to observe the 12CO(3-2) line at 345 GHz in band 7. Based on our single-dish CO(3-2) data and with the goal to detect a faintest level corresponding to 1/6 of the total emission, we estimate a peak flux density of 32 mJy/beam. We aim for a 5-sigma peak detection, and therefore expect an rms of 6.5 mJy per beam with channel width 10 km/s. The setups for band 3 will also allow us to obtain a continuum measurement (>20-sigma, estimated from our dust modeling of the Herschel and LABOCA data which give a total flux density of 46mJy) at the same angular resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This proposal is designed to address a major issue in understanding the ISM properties of low-metallicity starburst galaxies: the lack of molecular gas despite active star formation. Indeed, the molecular gas reservoir is difficult to measure at low metallicity as CO is more prone to photodissociation by hard radiation fields than H2. With vigorous star formation, bright far-infrared lines (including [CII] from our Herschel survey), but little detected HI and CO, the low-metallicity starburst galaxy Haro11 stands as a clear outlier from the Schmidt-Kennicutt relation. Known as a local analogue of Lyman break galaxies, it serves as the template for high-redshift galaxies and it is the best case to study the gas-star formation cycle under such extreme conditions. We propose band 3, 6, and 7 observations of the CO lines to localize the cold, star-forming gas in Haro11 at 1" resolution, probe spatially the gas excitation and physical conditions (densities, filling factors, optical depth, etc.), and determine accurately its total molecular gas reservoir.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal is a resubmission of your Cycle 2 project 2013.1.00350.S (PI Cormier). Any science goal completed by the end of Cycle 2 need not to be repeated in Cycle 3.
